title: Social Distancing
intro:
Many people close to me are skeptical that covid-19 is a big deal.
          I've made this illustration to show how your action will affect you,
          your household, and the community around you. All equations are based
          on the latest infection growth and fatality rates of the virus as of
          March 14, 2020.

infected.title: Megfertőződtél
infected.paragraph1: Let's roll the dice and see if it kills any of your family. It probably won't.
infected.paragraph2:
As expected, you probably didn't die. But it's not about you. Let's look
        at how many people your family is going to kill by not practicing social
        distancing.
infected.paragraph3: Unless you're over 60, or are immuno-comprimised (lots of your friends and family are!) you're going to have to click the button a lot before you die.
infected.paragraph4: So this is just like the flu, right?
infected.paragraph5: Nem egeszen. People have been quoting how many deaths per year there are for the flu (<1 href="https://www.cdc.gov/flu/about/burden/index.html#:~:text="> 12,000 to 61,000 </1>) to the deaths so far with coronavirus (<3 href="https://www.cnn.com/interactive/2020/health/coronavirus-maps-and-cases/">~50</3>) in the US.
infected.paragraph6: To get the full story you usually have to look at more than static numbers. In this case, we need to look at:
infected.paragraph7: The flu has a general fatality rate of 0.1% <1 /> COVID-19's fatality rate right now is 3.4%
infected.paragraph8: <0 href="https://www.sciencealert.com/covid-19-s-death-rate-is-higher-than-thought-but-it-should-drop">That's 34x</0>. The red bar here is 34 times bigger.
infected.paragraph9: It's easy to tell this virus is worse even without all the data, <1>the flu doesn't completely overwhelm the health care system</1> in Italy each year, but <3 href="https://www.theatlantic.com/ideas/archive/2020/03/who-gets-hospital-bed/607807/">that's exactly what coronavirus has done</3>.
infected.paragraph10: But still, only ~50 deaths in the US right? What's the big deal?
infected.paragraph11: The big deal is mixing a fatality rate that's 34x of the flu with exponential growth.

killers.title: Your Kill Count
killers.paragraph1: Social distancing is about how many people you want to kill (I hope that's zero). Right now, a COVID-19 infected person infects two more.
killers.paragraph2: So you infect two people, and next week they infect two people each, and then they infect two more, etc. etc.
killers.paragraph3: Go ahead and click the button
killers.paragraph4: So please, stay home. And while you're there <1 href="https://medium.com/@joschabach/flattening-the-curve-is-a-deadly-delusion-eea324fe9727">I think this article is worth your time</1>. Containment seems to be the best action right now given the numbers.
killers.paragraph5: <0 to={`/infected${location.search}`}>On the previous page we looked at the fatality rate</0> of COVID-19 and saw that statistically, you and your family will probably be fine, but social distancing isn't about you.
killers.paragraph6: What really sucks about this virus vs. the flu is that you can carry it around with you for weeks infecting people before you even know you have it. There is no way to know until it's too late. That's why containment is so important.
killers.paragraph7: You just saw that logarithmic growth is a powerful thing. The coronavirus is following a nearly perfect logarithmic curve in the US--even with our low levels of testing. While network marketers hope to use it in their favor to gain financial independence, a virus doesn't have to be convinced to keep the downline going.
killers.paragraph8: The <1>Attack Rate</1> of COVID-19 is estimated by the World Health Organization to be <3 href="https://www.worldometers.info/coronavirus/#repro">between 1.4 and 2.5</3>. That means if you get it, you're going to infect 2 other people (other studies have it as high as 4!). By comparison, the flu is 1.3 and anything less than 1 will just die off.
